summary: This is an email chain from July 2019 between FBI personnel and US Attorney's Office prosecutors regarding the scanning of case records from two FBI case files (72-MM-113327 and 31E-MM-108062) related to the Epstein investigation. The emails discuss logistics, deadlines, and the discovery of missing documents and pornographic images of young girls that were not scanned per protocol.

persons.name: Sean
persons.context: FBI SSA coordinating the shipment of case record boxes for scanning, provides FedEx tracking information.

persons.name: Maurene Comey
persons.context: Prosecutor from the Southern District of New York working on the investigation, provides contact information and details about the case files.

connections.description: Coordinating the scanning and transfer of Epstein case records between the FBI and the US Attorney's Office.

events.title: Shipment of case records
events.description: 22 boxes of case records from FBI case files 72-MM-113327 and 31E-MM-108062 are shipped via FedEx for scanning.

events.title: Scanning completion and discovery of issues
events.description: FBI reports finishing scanning, discovers three missing 1As (1A10, 1A28, 1A84) and two missing serials, and notes pornographic images of young girls were not scanned per protocol.

events.title: Prior scanning by Miami Field Office
events.description: Miami Field Office had requested some of the same case records to be scanned in 2013.

keyFacts: The document references two specific FBI case files: 72-MM-113327 and 31E-MM-108062, which are part of the Epstein investigation.
During scanning, FBI personnel discovered 'pornographic images of young girls' in the case records which were not scanned per protocol due to being possible child pornography.
Three 1A documents (1A10, 1A28, 1A84) and two serials from file 31E-MM-108062 were missing from the physical files and had to be regenerated from a digital copy.
The email chain shows coordination between the FBI's investigative team and prosecutors from the US Attorney's Office for the Southern District of New York in July 2019.
The correspondence indicates the materials were being prepared for discovery in an ongoing legal proceeding.
